title: Monday, 15th January, 2018

PM11:03am

Further to the announcement made on 12 January 2018, Carillion continued to engage with its key financial and other stakeholders, including Her Majesty's Government ('HMG'), over the course of the weekend regarding options to reduce debt and strengthen the group's balance sheet. As part of this engagement, Carillion also asked those stakeholders for limited short term financial support, to enable it to continue to trade whilst longer term engagement continued.

Despite considerable efforts, those discussions have not been successful, and the board of Carillion has therefore concluded that it had no choice but to take steps to enter into compulsory liquidation with immediate effect. An application was made to the High Court for a compulsory liquidation of Carillion before opening of business today and an order has been granted to appoint the Official Receiver as the liquidator of Carillion. We anticipate that the Official Receiver will make an application to the High Court for PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP to be appointed as Special Managers, to act on behalf of the Official Receiver, and we further anticipate that an order will be granted to that effect.

UBS:

BE11:12am

Ultimately the situation around Carillion is a function of a competitive outsourcing and construction markets in the UK, amplified by excessive financial leverage which has built up over recent years. While the departure of a competitor may ease this, we think the impact will likely be small given the fragmented nature of the market. We think there is some risk of financial losses in joint ventures as well as the potential adverse financial impact on the supply chain which may impact others in the sector. It may also result in a review of the level of outsourcing of public services although we note that most losses came from the construction business.

Manxish Carillion saga also spells out the dangers of Govt contracts that force liability for delays and overspends onto the developer. Though, of course, if this weren't the case then Govt would be getting in the neck for giving sweetheart deals that leave the taxpayer on the hook.
Mouselet I am confused by constructionenquirer.com stating both 'work stops on many Carillon projects' and 'PwC telling subcontractors and staff to continue working as normal'

Nately Everyone RNS'ing "business as usual, no effect" except BBY who admit £35-£45m. Hmm. I believe BBY.
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Cazenove.

BE11:12am

We do not think there is any exposure to the primary construction projects (three of which are partly responsible for the failure of the business), but Carillion has a substantial facilities management (FM) business where it provides soft services to schools, hospitals etc. While it is the ultimate responsibility of the project company to provide these services, Carillion’s announcement this morning states that “HM Government will be providing the necessary funding required by the Official Receiver to maintain the public services carried on by Carillion staff, subcontractors and suppliers." This should ensure that staff turn up for work and there is no interruption in services over the short term, which in turn means that the project companies will still be paid. Over the course of the next few weeks and perhaps months, other FM providers will take on Carillion’s FM contracts, and probably the staff. We see the main risk from this process as being frictional costs and a potential increase in price for the same services, although we do not think they are particularly out of line with market levels to which they are regularly benchmarked.

red @Lemmy no sense in taking over. look at the debt to deal with. sense in cherry picking contracts. but you can do that by stepping in as a white knight on a contract basis after failure and not be saddled with rest of it.

In fact, on the contrary, Carillion’s losses on some big primary PFI projects have shown that there is real risk transfer from the public sector to the private sector.

Stifel:

BE11:13am

Given that Carillion's difficulties have been well flagged for the past 6 months, it is fair to say that the listed infrastructure management teams have seen this coming and say they have contingency plans in anticipation of Carillion failing. We assume this includes having the potential to appoint other operators to these projects. Whilst this disruption could take up management time, we do not expect there to be any material impact on the valuation of the PFI projects in the listed funds portfolios.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And RBC:

BE11:13am

Whilst the government’s move to provide necessary funding is comforting, we are more encouraged that HICL has taken steps to not only mitigate its exposure to Carillion, but also plan in advance of today’s Carillion announcement. Firstly, Serco is anticipated to take over certain healthcare contracts from Carillion as part of a sale of contracts, and these contracts make up 6% of the 14% total exposure. Secondly, HICL is already in discussions with alternative contractors should there be a need to replace Carillion. This is done to ensure HICL’s stakeholders (especially the underlying users of the infrastructure) do not have their services disrupted and for HICL to ensure there’s a long-term solution in place. In other words, these plans can be implemented at short notice to ensure continuity of service provision, with the aim that affected PPP projects continue to perform in line with contractual requirements should alternative contracts be signed on, we believe the new rates charged will similarly be priced at market rates as those by Carillion. As such, the financial impact from this should be minimal, especially since HICL has already provisioned £5-10m at 1H18 results in response to its counterparty exposure among others.

And in terms of the shockwaves .....

BE11:17am

There are inevitably questions about the ability of the supply chain to withstand this shock. We believe there are two key mitigating factors; 1) The industry is very fragmented, Carillion arguably only has 3% share of wider industry, and 2) Carillion has used supply chain financing or reverse factoring, which means that some trade creditors were taking payments early, with the help of the banks. Carillion tended to rely more on sub-contractors than builders merchants, which means that the liquidation will only affect companies with similar supply chains. All companies closely monitor their own supply chains. The risk is that failures among tier two suppliers and below, feed back up the system towards the tier one contractors.

BE11:45am

On the indicative terms, accepting an offer would, we estimate, translate to a 12.5% lower value longer term for GKN shareholders (sum-of-the-parts 546p against 624p) than self-help, the upside being dilution from existing Melrose equity. However, a proven management team suggests lower execution risk and Melrose has a strong track record on disposals and garnering such premium. We also note that Melrose margin improvements have averaged 7% on its four deals suggesting they may well be eyeing greater upside than the c.250bps target of the current GKN management team. We move from buy to hold awaiting development but would be surprised if Melrose does not look to return.

hedgehog IWG this week ?

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Our analysis suggests that significant value will accrue to both existing Melrose and GKN shareholders should Melrose be successful in its pursuit of GKN and then deliver on its plan to improve operational performance. Based on our acquisition scenario and assuming that MRO could release GBP600mn of cash from GKN’s balance sheet, we believe Melrose could add 110p to the value of its shares and 172p to the value of GKN’s shares

BE11:47am

Although we believe GKN shareholders should ultimately accept a new offer from Melrose, there is a risk that a deal might not be reached. Therefore, for our base-case valuation we assign 70% of our estimated value creation from a potential deal with GKN when valuing Melrose. Even if Melrose doesn’t get GKN, this approach reminds the market it is actively seeking the next deal.

BE11:47am

Berenberg keep buying.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

We applaud GKN’s two-year performance improvement
initiative (“Project Boost”) and decision to separate the aerospace and
automotive businesses. In the absence of a bid, we believe these initiatives
would have driven the shares to at least the 400p level, or near our
undisturbed sum-of-the-parts (SOTP) valuation of 405p. However, Melrose’s
management has an excellent track record of improving underperforming
industrial assets and if we assume the offer is increased (we suggest 455p),
the decision for shareholders will ultimately come down to which team it
trusts to achieve the most value creation. On this basis, a similar deal
structure offering just over 80% in Melrose shares would allow GKN
shareholders to crystallise almost a fifth of their holding in cash at a 37%
premium to the pre-bid price, and still participate in any upside through its
equity holding in Melrose (we estimate just over 60% of the enlarged group
on a raised bid). We believe investors are unlikely to reject such an offer.

BE11:51am

GKN’s pension scheme was closed to further accrual in 2017 as part of an agreement to make a one-off £250m payment into the scheme. This make it possible for a full or partial buyout of the scheme to de-risk the pension situation (buyouts are not possible for active schemes). [In September w]e estimated the buy-out deficit to be £1.8bn by applying a 30% buyout premium to the IAS 19 obligations
(from H1 17) and subtracting this from the IAS 19 asset values. Since H1 17 factors affecting the IAS 19 obligation have become more favourable so we estimate the buy-out deficit will have reduced. A crude analysis implies that there is a £1bn premium to eliminate
all pension risk (the buyout deficit of slightly less than £1.8bn minus the ~£0.6bn deficit).

BE12:03pm

The anticipated stronger H2 performance has not materialised so
the FY result is now expected to be significantly lower than previously planned. As a consequence of delayed projects and lower customer orders, the Board has also reduced its profit expectations for FY2019. However, the Group’s financing remains healthy and it continues to operate well within its banking covenants. We have cut our FY18 and FY19 PBT forecasts by 30%. The shares have been hit hard on this morning’s news, despite the significant underperformance over the last six months. At this level, we see recovery value if Management can deliver on the revised forecasts.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

(Yes, Singer notes are now useless.)

BE12:03pm

We have cut our Mar’18 PBT by 30% to £9.0m (9.0p). Most of the damage is at
Technical Plastics, which accounts for £2.8m of the £4.0m EBITA miss this year, but the Wipac & Aerospace EBITA forecasts have also been cut. The size of the downgrade reflects the large contribution from tooling profits and the degree of fixed costs, so the delayed contract awarding has a disproportionate impact on profits. We have also cut our Mar’19 PBT by 30% from £15.4m to £11.0m
(10.9p). In theory, the contract slippage from H2 this year, into next and the
ramp up in medium-volume Wipac programmes towards the end of next year should underpin the FY2019 profit forecast. However, we are choosing to adopt a far more conservative approach.
